subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. You know, I realize
that I often just start these monologues
by laughing. I think the ultimate
thing I'm laughing about is the very
idea that I'm here, you know in my
71st year all of a sudden I‘ve decided
to do monologues. It seems kind of
ironic to me because I never really
thought of myself as much of an
entertainer or even a funny person. I'
ve basically been a teacher, a lecturer, a
serious person in my life. But when I sit
here in this chair all of a sudden
everything seems funny. I'm under the
impression that there's actually a
cosmic truth to that - that
there's something
inherently funny about the universe
itself. The irony of course is that
there's everything about the universe
itself. There's something very tragic
about the universe itself. And yet, the
idea that the universe could be tragic
is also funny. I don't know. Maybe I'm
just in a mood, a peculiar mood. You
would say there is something very
passionate, very loving about
the universe. Yet, even that kind of
seems funny. The idea that the universe
could even be tragic strikes me as
funny. How can the universe be tragic? I
mean, let's face it.
If we're looking at the
universe purely logically, there should
be no universe. Why should there be
anything at all? So, the fact that there
is a universe - what are we to make of it?
I guess the first question people ask is,
is it meaningful? Is there a
purpose, is there a function? Is there
meaning to be found in the fact that we
exist? Well, the existential
philosophers and many other philosophers,
postmodern philosophers in general, are
coming around to thinking, "No, there's no
meaning to any of it. The only
meaning that there is is the meaning
that we create." Why do we create
meaning at all? It's to satisfy our needs.
How are we going to get a little
more food, ultimately? Or a little more of
whatever it is that we desire. How are we
going to fulfill our desires?
That's how we create meaning, which
in a way seems perfectly natural,
perfectly logical, and in another
way, perfectly pathetic. Is that the best
we can do when we're looking for meaning -
how am I going to get my needs met? And
yet, if we don't get our needs met, where
are we? Speaking of needs, I don't know that
psychic functioning has ever come up in
any of the classical psychological
studies of human needs. There's Maslow's
hierarchy of needs, for example. He
talks about self-actualization, he talks
about
mystical experiences even being a sign
of self-actualization. He calls it a peak
experience. But, he doesn't address the
question of parapsychology at all.
Does anybody need to be psychic? I think
most of us would say, "No. I'm going to have a
good life or at least it's not going to
be any worse if I'm not psychic." Because,
let's face it, the most
psychic people among us are mostly not
psychic. I mean, a great psychic - the Ted
Owens of the world, the Uri Geller's
of the world - are like great baseball
players, like Babe Ruth, they strike out
more often than they hit home runs. So, who
needs that? If being psychic isn't a
human need, well, where does it fit?
I guess we could call
it a human potential, and a very, very
rudimentary human potential I would say,
on this planet amongst this human
species. Well, we don't really know. You
know, it seems as if in some
circumstances psychic functioning might
be highly refined and maybe we haven't
yet quite got the way to perceive it.
I suppose you could consider it
like electricity. In the early
days when people studied electricity…
when Benjamin Franklin flew a kite and
tied a key onto the kite string and
found that lightning would strike the
key and began to develop his theories of
electricity based on that we had a very
rudimentary understanding of electricity.
It wasn't really used for anyt
hing much. I mean, we knew about certain
animals, like certain fish that would
have an electrical charge on them. But, we
didn't have a technology the way we have
today where our whole civilization is
run on electricity. Maybe the same is
true of psychic functioning. It seems
like a kind of will-o'-wisp function
for the most part. Parapsychologists
like myself are the most marginalized of
all researchers. And yet, I think someday
it will become central.
I think most people if you were to
ask them today, civilized people, do you
need electricity? Well, 200-300
years ago, of course the answer would
have been no. Most people wouldn't even
know what electricity was. But today, if
you want to live in the civilized way, of
course you need electricity. Even in
third world countries, even in the most
rural backward areas now you have
electricity. I remember when I visited
China, that would have been over 30 years
ago the first time, in the mid-1980s,
it was… I mean, it's a very advanced
civilization today for sure. But back
then we ate at a restaurant where they
just had a dirt floor. But, they did have
a light bulb hanging from the ceiling.
Even there they had electricity, of
course. So, psychic functioning could be
like that. It could be something that
someday we will all need, that if you
don't have it, you'd fall way
behind. Now, knowing that that might be
the case in the future, how does that
affect your thinking about it now?
Maybe it's something that we need
because it is
a rudimentary highly undeveloped potential?
Maybe we need it all the more. I don't know.
I think each of you have
the ability to determine for yourself
whether you think this is something
you need. If you're watching these
videos of me, is it because I'm
happy and make you laugh? I have to say, I
don't laugh this much in my life
normally. I do not. But there's
something about being alone in this room
while I'm simultaneously talking to, let
us say, about 1,000 people or more,
it tickles my funny
bone. It makes me appreciate the
delightful hilarity in which we're immersed
and I'm very grateful for that
because, you know, for most of my life I
don't think I appreciated just how
hilarious everything is. But,
it does remind me of a tai chi
teacher I had many years ago who told me
that when you're doing tai chi really
well, the great masters of tai chi are
always, he said, on the edge of hilarity.
So, in a way, maybe these monologues are a
form of tai chi for me. I'd also want
to point out that I've tried to
downplay this notion of transmission.
I don't want to make it like,
"This is a cult.
You are being magnetized by me." No,
nothing at all like that. But, I do think
that the humor that is somehow
possessing me, that everything seems so
funny, is part of the transmission. It is.
I think, probably, the message is
not to take yourself too
seriously. My sense is, especially among
some of my critics who I love and
who post often wonderful comments, and
I have to say I learn so much from
the people who comment on these videos. I
do. But, I also get the sense that
sometimes you take yourself too
seriously, especially those of you who
disagree with me politically. So, that's
the thought I'm going to leave
you with. Are you taking yourself too
seriously, one way or another? If so, what
can you do about it? What would
tickle your funny bone? How can you begin
to see more of the humor in life? I
don't mean haha humor - I mean see, as my
tai chi teacher once said, how
can you bring yourself right to the edge
of hilarity? And if you do, what will
come of that? What will come out of more
laughter, more hilarity in your life? I'll
leave you with that thought. Thank
you, thank you for being with me.
